name: Sprint Planning
objective: Determine what can be delivered in the Sprint and how that work will be achieved.
description: This event initiates the sprint. The entire Scrum Team collaborates to determine what can be delivered and, crucially, how that work will be achieved. It involves crafting a Sprint Goal that provides coherence to the selected work items and breaking down High-Level items into actionable tasks.

activities.name: Establish Capacity
activities.description: Review team availability and historical velocity to determine capacity.

activities.name: Draft Sprint Goal
activities.description: Product Owner proposes a goal; the team refines it to ensure it provides focus.

activities.name: Select Items
activities.description: Developers pull items from the Product Backlog that align with the Goal.

activities.name: Decompose Work
activities.description: Break down selected items into technical tasks.

work_products.name: Sprint Goal
work_products.description: A short, coherent objective for the Sprint.

work_products.name: Sprint Backlog
work_products.description: Selected items and the plan to deliver them.

completion_criteria: Sprint Goal is defined and Sprint Backlog is populated within team capacity.

pitfalls: Overallocating work beyond team capacity.
Focusing on filling the bucket rather than the Goal.
benefits: Reduces uncertainty by detailed task planning.

name: Daily Scrum
objective: Inspect progress toward the Sprint Goal and adapt the Sprint Backlog.
description: A 15-minute time-boxed event for the Developers. The purpose is to synchronize activities and plan for the next 24 hours. It is not a status report to management, but a coordination meeting to identify impediments and ensure the Sprint Goal is on track.

activities.name: Review Board
activities.description: Walk the board from right (done) to left (to do).

activities.name: Identify Blockers
activities.description: Raise any impediments preventing progress.

activities.name: Adapt Plan
activities.description: Adjust the daily plan based on progress.

work_products.name: Updated Sprint Backlog
work_products.description: Reflects current progress.

completion_criteria: Team has a plan for the next 24 hours; impediments are logged.

pitfalls: Turning it into a status report for the Scrum Master.
Problem-solving during the 15 minutes (should be taken offline).

name: User Stories
objective: Define requirements in small, client-valued functional increments.
description: Work is divided into functional increments called 'user stories', following the '3 Cs' model: Card (physical token), Conversation (verbal discussion), and Confirmation (acceptance criteria). They shift focus from writing documentation to talking about the requirement.

activities.name: Write Card
activities.description: Stakeholder writes a brief reminder of value (As a... I want... So that...).

activities.name: Refine
activities.description: Team clarifies details via conversation.

activities.name: Confirm
activities.description: Define acceptance criteria (Gherkin or bullet points).

work_products.name: Story Card
work_products.description: The physical or digital representation of the requirement.

completion_criteria: Story satisfies INVEST criteria (Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, Testable).

pitfalls: Creating 'technical stories' meant only for developers.
Treating the card as a detailed specification document.
benefits: Mitigates risk of misunderstanding through conversation.

name: Planning Poker
objective: Collaboratively estimate work complexity using a relative scale to reach consensus.
description: A consensus-based technique where teams assign relative effort values (often using the Fibonacci sequence: 1, 2, 3, 5, 8...) to work items. Members reveal estimates simultaneously to avoid anchoring bias, followed by a discussion of outliers to build shared understanding.

activities.name: Present Item
activities.description: Product Owner reads the story and answers questions.

activities.name: Vote
activities.description: Team members select a card privately and reveal simultaneously.

activities.name: Discuss
activities.description: High and low estimators explain their reasoning.

activities.name: Re-Vote
activities.description: Repeat until convergence/consensus.

work_products.name: Estimated Backlog
work_products.description: Backlog items with assigned Story Points.

completion_criteria: Consensus reached on the relative size of the item.

pitfalls: Equating points directly to hours.
Debating small differences (e.g., 3 vs 5) for too long.
benefits: Builds team ownership of the plan.

name: Test-Driven Development (TDD)
objective: Ensure code is testable, covered by regression tests, and designed simply.
description: A software engineering practice where tests are written before the production code. It follows the 'Red-Green-Refactor' cycle: Write a failing test (Red), write just enough code to pass it (Green), and optimize the code (Refactor).

activities.name: Red
activities.description: Write a small unit test that fails.

activities.name: Green
activities.description: Write the minimum code necessary to make the test pass.

activities.name: Refactor
activities.description: Clean up the code structure while keeping tests passing.

work_products.name: Unit Tests
work_products.description: Automated suite of tests.

work_products.name: Clean Code
work_products.description: Implementated code.

completion_criteria: Code is committed only when all tests pass (Green bar).

metrics.name: Code Coverage
metrics.formula: Lines of Code Executed by Tests / Total Lines of Code * 100

pitfalls: Writing the test after the code.
Skipping the Refactor step (accumulating technical debt).

name: Acceptance Test-Driven Development (ATDD)
objective: Collaborate to define completion criteria and write acceptance tests before implementation.
description: This practice involves the 'Three Amigos' (Business, Development, QA) meeting before development begins to discuss requirements and derive acceptance tests. These tests often serve as the requirements themselves. It ensures that the team solves the right problem.

activities.name: Workshop
activities.description: The Three Amigos discuss the user story and explore edge cases.

activities.name: Formulate
activities.description: Write acceptance tests (e.g., in Gherkin syntax).

activities.name: Automate
activities.description: Connect the tests to the system (often failing initially).

activities.name: Implement
activities.description: Develop code until acceptance tests pass.

work_products.name: Acceptance Tests
work_products.description: Executable specifications.

work_products.name: Examples
work_products.description: Concrete scenarios clarifying the rule.

completion_criteria: Shared understanding reached and acceptance tests defined.

pitfalls: Testing only the 'happy path'.
QA writing tests in isolation after development.

name: Visualize the Workflow (Kanban Board)
objective: Make hidden work and bottlenecks immediately apparent.
description: Teams create a visual model of their work process, typically on a Kanban Board. Columns represent different process states (e.g., Analysis, Development, Testing). This visualization supports transparency and makes bottlenecks visible.

activities.name: Map Process
activities.description: Define the steps a work item takes from start to finish.

activities.name: Construct Board
activities.description: Create columns for each step.

activities.name: Populate
activities.description: Place current work items on the board.

work_products.name: Kanban Board
work_products.description: Physical or digital representation of work.

completion_criteria: Board accurately reflects the real-time state of work.

metrics.name: Throughput
metrics.formula: Number of Completed Items / Time Period

metrics.name: Work In Progress (WIP)
metrics.formula: Count of Items in 'In Progress' Columns

pitfalls: Board becoming a 'zombie' (not updated).
Visualizing the wishful process instead of the actual process.

name: Continuous Integration
objective: Detect integration errors immediately by merging code frequently.
description: Developers merge their code into a shared repository multiple times a day. Each merge triggers an automated build and test sequence. This practice minimizes 'integration hell' and ensures the software is always in a releasable state.

activities.name: Commit
activities.description: Developer pushes code to the main branch.

activities.name: Build
activities.description: CI Server compiles the code.

activities.name: Test
activities.description: CI Server runs automated unit and integration tests.

work_products.name: Build Artifact
work_products.description: Deployable package.

work_products.name: Build Report
work_products.description: Status of the integration (Pass/Fail).

completion_criteria: The build is green (passing) and deployed to an integration environment.

metrics.name: Build Repair Time
metrics.formula: Time Build Fixed - Time Build Broke

pitfalls: Committing to a feature branch that lives for days.
Broken builds being ignored.

name: Pair Programming
objective: Enhance code quality and knowledge sharing by having two developers work on one machine.
description: Two developers work at one workstation. One, the 'driver,' writes code while the other, the 'navigator,' reviews each line as it is typed, considering the strategic direction. They switch roles frequently to maintain focus and energy.

activities.name: Setup
activities.description: Two developers sit at one computer.

activities.name: Drive/Navigate
activities.description: Perform the coding task collaboratively.

activities.name: Rotate
activities.description: Switch roles every few minutes or when a test passes.

work_products.name: Production Code
work_products.description: High-quality, reviewed code.

completion_criteria: Code is committed by the pair.

pitfalls: Navigator checking their phone (disengagement).
Domination by the more senior developer.

name: Refactoring
objective: Improve internal structure without changing external behavior.
description: The continuous improvement of the code's design to keep it clean, understandable, and maintainable. It prevents 'bit rot' and technical debt accumulation. It is distinct from rewriting; it involves small, safe transformations.

activities.name: Identify Smell
activities.description: Locate complex, duplicate, or unclear code.

activities.name: Transform
activities.description: Apply a refactoring pattern (e.g., Extract Method).

activities.name: Verify
activities.description: Run tests to ensure behavior is unchanged.

work_products.name: Clean Code
work_products.description: Codebase free of duplication and complexity.

completion_criteria: Code passes all tests and is structurally better.

pitfalls: Refactoring without test coverage.
Refactoring for days without delivering value (Gold Plating).

name: Definition of Done (DoD)
objective: Create a shared understanding of quality standards and eliminate ambiguity.
description: A comprehensive checklist of requirements (e.g., tested, reviewed, documented) that must be fulfilled before a user story or product increment can be considered complete. It acts as a quality gate ensuring the increment is potentially shippable.

activities.name: Draft
activities.description: Team brainstorms all necessary quality steps.

activities.name: Agree
activities.description: Commit to the list as a team.

activities.name: Apply
activities.description: Verify every item against the DoD before marking 'Complete'.

work_products.name: DoD Checklist
work_products.description: Visible list of completion criteria.

completion_criteria: DoD is visible and applied to every item.

pitfalls: Making the DoD so stringent that nothing ever gets done.
Ignoring the DoD under pressure.

name: Weighted Shortest Job First (WSJF)
objective: Sequence work to maximize economic benefit.
description: A prioritization mechanism used to sequence jobs (features) to produce maximum economic benefit. It calculates a score by dividing the Cost of Delay (CoD) by the Job Duration (or size).

activities.name: Calculate CoD
activities.description: Sum of User Value + Time Criticality + Risk Reduction.

activities.name: Estimate Size
activities.description: Determine relative duration/size of the job.

activities.name: Prioritize
activities.description: Rank items by WSJF score (highest first).

work_products.name: Prioritized Backlog
work_products.description: List of features sorted by economic value.

completion_criteria: Backlog is ordered by WSJF score.

pitfalls: Spending too much time calculating precise numbers for CoD.
Gaming the size estimates to get a higher score.

name: Story Mapping
objective: Organize user stories to understand the whole product and user journey.
description: A visualization technique that organizes user activities (the backbone) horizontally and breaks them down into details/stories vertically. It helps teams understand the product narrative, identify gaps, and plan releases based on user flow rather than random features.

activities.name: Build Backbone
activities.description: Identify high-level user activities (left to right).

activities.name: Break Down
activities.description: Add user tasks/stories under each activity.

activities.name: Slice Releases
activities.description: Draw horizontal lines to define MVPs and subsequent releases.

work_products.name: Story Map
work_products.description: Visual representation of the user journey and backlog.

completion_criteria: Map reveals a cohesive user journey and release slices.

pitfalls: Creating a map and never updating it.
Too much detail in the initial mapping.
benefits: Builds shared understanding of the 'Big Picture'.

name: Lean Coffee
objective: Collectively build and prioritize discussion agendas for structured meetings.
description: A structured, agenda-less meeting format where participants build the agenda democratically. Topics are generated on sticky notes, voted on, and discussed in strict time-boxed intervals (e.g., 5 mins + 2 mins extension).

activities.name: Generate
activities.description: Everyone writes topics on sticky notes.

activities.name: Vote
activities.description: Dot voting to prioritize topics.

activities.name: Discuss
activities.description: Discuss top items in timeboxes; vote to extend or end.

work_products.name: Prioritized Agenda
work_products.description: List of discussed topics.

completion_criteria: Timebox expires or topics run out.

pitfalls: Using it for meetings that require a pre-set decision (e.g., architectural review).
Lack of facilitation leading to aimless chatting.
benefits: Ensures participants discuss what matters to them.

name: Mob Programming
objective: The entire (or part of ) team works on the same task at the same time.
description: An extension of Pair Programming where the whole team (3+ people) works on the same thing, at the same time, in the same space, and at the same computer. It optimizes for flow efficiency over resource efficiency.

activities.name: Assemble
activities.description: Team gathers at one screen.

activities.name: Rotate Driver
activities.description: Driver changes every 10-15 minutes.

activities.name: Navigate
activities.description: Rest of the team guides the driver.

work_products.name: Production Code
work_products.description: Code produced by the mob.

completion_criteria: Task is completed and committed.

pitfalls: Passive team members tuning out.
Exhaustion (requires frequent breaks).
benefits: High quality code with few defects.
No need for separate code reviews.

name: Value Stream Mapping
objective: Visualize the end-to-end flow of work to identify and remove waste.
description: A Lean management practice that maps the steps a product takes from request to delivery. It specifically measures 'value-added time' versus 'wait time' to calculate flow efficiency and identifies value-creating and non-value-creating actions to eliminate waste.

activities.name: Select Product Family
activities.description: Identify the product family to map.

activities.name: Create Current State Map
activities.description: Walk the flow and capture the actual condition of material and information flow (cycle times, inventory, etc.).

activities.name: Create Future State Map
activities.description: Design the target condition using lean guidelines (Takt time, continuous flow, supermarkets).

activities.name: Develop Implementation Plan
activities.description: Create a plan to move from current to future state.

work_products.name: Current State Map
work_products.description: Visual diagram of current flow and metrics.

work_products.name: Future State Map
work_products.description: Visual diagram of desired flow.

completion_criteria: Future state map and implementation plan are agreed upon.

metrics.name: Flow Efficiency
metrics.formula: Value Added Time / Total Lead Time * 100

metrics.name: Lead Time
metrics.formula: Total time from order to delivery

pitfalls: Mapping the 'official' process instead of reality.
Analysis paralysis (spending too long mapping).
Mapping without walking the gemba
Focusing only on material flow and ignoring information flow
benefits: Focuses on the whole system, not just local optimization.

name: STATIK
objective: Design a Kanban system tailored to the service's specific context.
description: Systems Thinking Approach To Introducing Kanban. It is a repeatable, humane way to get started with Kanban by analyzing sources of dissatisfaction, demand, and capabilities before designing the board.

activities.name: Analyze Dissatisfaction
activities.description: Identify what makes the current process painful.

activities.name: Analyze Demand
activities.description: Understand what work comes in and how often.

activities.name: Analyze Capability
activities.description: Assess the team's ability to handle different work types.

activities.name: Model Workflow
activities.description: Define the activity states.

activities.name: Identify class of service
activities.description: Set WIP limits and class of service.

activities.name: Design System
activities.description: Create the board, limits, and classes of service.

work_products.name: Kanban System Design
work_products.description: The configuration of the board and policies.

completion_criteria: A Kanban system is ready to launch.

pitfalls: Designing the system in isolation without the team.
Copying another team's board without analysis.
benefits: Customizes Kanban to the specific team context.

name: Overall Retrospective
objective: Improve the organizational system in a multi-team context.
description: In large-scale environments (like LeSS), individual team retrospectives are insufficient. This practice brings representatives from multiple teams together to discuss systemic impediments that affect everyone.

activities.name: Gather
activities.description: Product Owner, Scrum Masters, and Team Reps meet.

activities.name: Discuss System
activities.description: Identify issues crossing team boundaries.

activities.name: Plan Action
activities.description: Decide on organizational experiments.

work_products.name: Improvement Plan
work_products.description: Actions for the next sprint.

completion_criteria: Systemic impediment identified and action planned.

pitfalls: Turning it into a complaint session without action.
Excluding management who have the power to change the system.
benefits: Solves problems that individual teams cannot fix.

name: Sprint Retrospective
objective: Inspect the past Sprint and plan for improvements
description: The Sprint Retrospective is held at the end of the Sprint to plan ways to increase quality and effectiveness. The Scrum Team inspects how the last Sprint went with regards to individuals, interactions, processes, tools, and their Definition of Done. Elements that went well and problems encountered are discussed, and the most helpful changes to improve the team's effectiveness are identified and planned for the next Sprint.

activities.name: Set the Stage
activities.description: Gather the Scrum Team and establish a safe environment for discussion.

activities.name: Review Data
activities.description: Inspect the Sprint events, velocity, and other relevant data.

activities.name: Generate Insights
activities.description: Discuss what went well, what could have been better, and identify root causes.

activities.name: Decide on Actions
activities.description: Select specific improvement actions to implement in the next Sprint.

activities.name: Close the Retrospective
activities.description: Formalize the plan and conclude the meeting.

work_products.name: Improvement Plan
work_products.description: A list of actionable improvements, often added to the Sprint Backlog for the next Sprint.

completion_criteria: Concrete improvement actions are identified and assigned.

guidelines.name: Scrum and XP from the Trenches

pitfalls: Focusing on who is at fault rather than process improvement.
Discussing problems without committing to concrete solutions.
Skipping the Event
Treating the retrospective as optional when under pressure.
benefits: Regularly enhances team effectiveness and product quality.
Provides a space to resolve interpersonal and process issues.

name: Sprint Review
objective: Inspect the outcome of the Sprint and determine future adaptations
description: The Sprint Review is held at the end of the Sprint to inspect the Increment and adapt the Product Backlog. The Scrum Team presents the results of their work to key stakeholders and progress toward the Product Goal is discussed. It is a working session where the Scrum Team and stakeholders collaborate on what to do next based on the inspection of the increment and changes in the environment.

activities.name: Present Done Items
activities.description: The Product Owner explains what Product Backlog items have been 'Done' and what has not.

activities.name: Discuss Development
activities.description: Developers discuss what went well during the Sprint, what problems they ran into, and how those problems were solved.

activities.name: Demonstrate Increment
activities.description: Developers demonstrate the work that was 'Done' and answer questions about the Increment.

activities.name: Review Product Backlog
activities.description: The Product Owner discusses the Product Backlog as it stands and projects likely target and delivery dates.

activities.name: Collaborate on Next Steps
activities.description: The entire group collaborates on what to do next, providing valuable input for the next Sprint Planning.

work_products.name: Updated Product Backlog
work_products.description: Adjustments to the backlog based on feedback and new insights.

work_products.name: Product Increment
work_products.description: The inspected and accepted working software.

completion_criteria: Feedback from stakeholders is gathered and the Product Backlog is updated.

guidelines.name: Scrum and XP from the Trenches

pitfalls: Presenting slides instead of working software.
Holding the review without the people who provide feedback.
Treating the event as a sign-off meeting rather than a collaborative working session.
benefits: Direct input from users and stakeholders on the product direction.
Ensures the Product Backlog remains relevant to current business needs.
Fosters collaboration between the Scrum Team and stakeholders.

name: Backlog Refinement
objective: Break down and further define Product Backlog items into smaller more precise items
description: Product Backlog refinement is the act of breaking down and further defining Product Backlog items into smaller more precise items. This is an ongoing activity to add details, such as a description, order, and size. Attributes often vary with the domain of work. The Developers who will be doing the work are responsible for the sizing. The Product Owner may influence the Developers by helping them understand and select trade-offs.

activities.name: Review and Clarify
activities.description: The Product Owner and Developers review high-priority backlog items to ensure a shared understanding of the scope and intent.

activities.name: Decomposition
activities.description: Large items are broken down into smaller, more manageable items that can be completed within a single Sprint.

activities.name: Estimation
activities.description: Developers provide an estimate of the effort or size required for the items, often using techniques like Planning Poker.

activities.name: Ordering
activities.description: The Product Owner re-orders the Product Backlog based on new insights, value, and estimates.

work_products.name: Product Backlog
work_products.description: An emergent, ordered list of what is needed to improve the product.

completion_criteria: Backlog items are deemed 'Ready' for selection in a Sprint Planning event (e.g., they are clear, feasible, and testable).

metrics.name: Ready Backlog Depth
metrics.formula: Sum(Size of Ready Items) / Average Velocity

guidelines.name: Scrum and XP from the Trenches

pitfalls: Wasting effort on items that may change or be discarded before they are needed.
The Product Owner refining in isolation, leading to lack of technical feasibility or buy-in.
benefits: Reduces the time required for Sprint Planning by ensuring items are already understood.
Identifies dependencies and unknowns early, before the Sprint begins.

name: Swarming
objective: Maximize flow and reduce cycle time by focusing collective team effort on finishing one item before starting another
description: Swarming is a collaborative technique where multiple team members with different skills focus their efforts on a single work item (such as a user story or support ticket) simultaneously to complete it as quickly as possible. Rather than working in silos or handing off tasks sequentially (e.g., from developer to tester), the team works in parallel or together to solve the problem. This approach minimizes 'Work in Progress' (WIP), improves flow, ensures shared understanding, and reduces the time it takes to deliver value.

activities.name: Identify Priority
activities.description: Select the critical user story or issue that requires immediate attention, often one that is blocked or closest to completion.

activities.name: Form Swarm
activities.description: Identify all team members capable of contributing to the item (e.g., Developer, Tester, Designer).

activities.name: Agree on Approach
activities.description: The group decides how to attack the work simultaneously (e.g., breaking down tasks to work in parallel or pairing/mobbing on a single screen).

activities.name: Execute and Integrate
activities.description: Team members work collaboratively in real-time to complete tasks, review code, and test immediately.

work_products.name: User Story
work_products.description: The functional increment being worked on by the swarm.

work_products.name: Support Ticket
work_products.description: The issue or incident being resolved (in IT support contexts).

work_products.name: Test Cases
work_products.description: Tests created and executed during the swarming process.

work_products.name: Production Code
work_products.description: Code developed, reviewed, and integrated during the swarming session.

completion_criteria: The User Story is 100% Done or the Issue is fully resolved with no remaining tasks.

guidelines.name: Swarming: A Team-Based Approach to Getting Work Done

pitfalls: High Work In Progress (WIP) if swarming is neglected
Team members struggling with autonomy initially
Focusing on individual efficiency metrics instead of flow
Lack of clear communication channels leading to confusion
benefits: Broader team understanding of the system
Real-time code review and quality assurance
Increased employee empowerment and skill development

name: Example Mapping
objective: Clarify and confirm acceptance criteria through a structured conversation using concrete examples.
description: Example Mapping is a simple, low-tech method for keeping story discovery conversations short and productive. It involves a group (typically the 'Three Amigos') using a pack of 4-colored index cards to capture different types of information (Story, Rules, Examples, Questions) as the conversation unfolds. This visual representation helps tease apart rules, identify core behaviors, and defer complexity, ensuring a shared understanding of what it takes for a story to be 'done' before development begins.

activities.name: Setup
activities.description: Write the User Story under discussion on a yellow card and place it at the top of the table.

activities.name: Map Rules
activities.description: Write known acceptance criteria or rules on blue cards and place them beneath the yellow story card.

activities.name: Create Examples
activities.description: For each rule, write one or more concrete examples (e.g., 'The one where...') on green cards to illustrate it and place them under the relevant rule.

activities.name: Capture Questions
activities.description: If questions arise that cannot be answered immediately, capture them on red cards to move the conversation forward.

activities.name: Review and Slice
activities.description: Assess the visual map. If there are too many blue cards (rules) or red cards (questions), consider slicing the story or deferring it for more research.

activities.name: Vote
activities.description: Conduct a quick thumb-vote after the timebox (e.g., 25 minutes) to decide if the story is ready for development.

work_products.name: Example Map
work_products.description: A visual arrangement of colored cards (Story, Rules, Examples, Questions) representing the shared understanding.

work_products.name: Refined User Story
work_products.description: A story that has been clarified, potentially sliced, or confirmed as ready for development.

work_products.name: List of Questions
work_products.description: Captured unknowns (red cards) requiring further research (known unknowns).

completion_criteria: The group is satisfied that the scope of the story is clear, or the 25-minute timebox has expired.

pitfalls: Writing formal Gherkin scenarios during the session (can be distracting)
Letting discussions ramble without capturing questions
Attempting to map stories that are too big or uncertain without slicing
Discussing opinions instead of capturing questions (red cards)
benefits: Acts as a filter to prevent large or unclear stories from entering sprints
Saves time and maintains interest of busy product people

name: Impact Mapping
objective: To create a visual hierarchy connecting business goals to specific features, ensuring value delivery.
description: Impact Mapping is a planning technique that creates a visual hierarchy from Goal to Actors (who can help/hinder), to Impacts (behavior changes), to Deliverables (features). It ensures every feature serves a business goal.

activities.name: Identify Goal
activities.description: Determine the central business goal to be achieved.

activities.name: Identify Actors
activities.description: Identify the people or groups who can help or hinder the achievement of the goal.

activities.name: Determine Impacts
activities.description: Define the behavior changes (impacts) required from the actors.

activities.name: Define Deliverables
activities.description: List the features or deliverables that will drive the desired impacts.

work_products.name: Impact Map
work_products.description: A visual hierarchy from Goal to Actors to Impacts to Deliverables.

completion_criteria: Map connects goals to deliverables.

guidelines.name: How Story Mapping and Impact Mapping Drive Alignment - Beyond the Backlog
Impact Mapping: Ultimate Guide for Product Teams - NEXT

pitfalls: Focusing on deliverables instead of impacts.
Creating a static map that is not updated.
benefits: Ensures every feature serves a business goa.

name: Opportunity Solution Trees
objective: Visualize discovery to stay aligned and drive outcomes
description: Opportunity solution trees are a visual representation of the paths a team might take to reach a desired outcome. The tree starts with a desired outcome at the root, branches into the opportunity space (customer needs, pain points, desires), then into the solution space, and finally into assumption tests to evaluate those solutions. This structure helps teams resolve the tension between business and customer needs and build a shared understanding.

activities.name: Verify Prerequisites
activities.description: Ensure the team has a clear outcome, a theory of the target customer/value proposition, and has conducted at least 3 story-based customer interviews.

activities.name: Define Outcome
activities.description: Place the clearly defined desired outcome (typically a product outcome) at the top of the tree.

activities.name: Map Opportunity Space
activities.description: Synthesize findings from customer interviews (often using an experience map) to group needs and pain points under the outcome.

activities.name: Select Target Opportunity
activities.description: Choose one specific opportunity to focus on to limit work in progress and deliver value iteratively.

activities.name: Brainstorm Solutions
activities.description: Generate potential solutions specifically for the selected target opportunity, not the whole tree.

activities.name: Select Solutions to Explore
activities.description: Choose three solutions to move forward with for comparison and contrasting.

activities.name: Identify Assumptions
activities.description: Break the selected solutions down into their underlying assumptions (desirability, viability, feasibility, usability).

activities.name: Test Assumptions
activities.description: Run rapid tests on the riskiest assumptions across the three ideas to gather data.

activities.name: Evaluate and Decide
activities.description: Use test data to decide whether to throw ideas away, refine them, or pivot to a new opportunity.

work_products.name: Opportunity Solution Tree
work_products.description: A visual diagram connecting the desired outcome to opportunities, solutions, and assumption tests

work_products.name: Experience Map
work_products.description: A visual map of the customer's experience used to structure the opportunity space

work_products.name: Assumption Tests
work_products.description: Experiments designed to validate or invalidate the risks associated with potential solutions

completion_criteria: The team has evaluated solutions based on assumption test data and decided on the next step (iterate, pivot, or deliver).

metrics.name: Business Outcome

name: Definition of Ready
objective: Ensure backlog items are actionable, clear, and feasible before work begins
description: The Definition of Ready (DoR) is a working agreement and a set of criteria that a Product Backlog Item must meet before it can be selected for a Sprint. It acts as a gateway or checklist to ensure that work is sufficiently defined, free of external dependencies, and properly estimated, preventing the team from committing to ambiguous or unfeasible work. This practice facilitates the transition of work from the Product Backlog to the development stage.

activities.name: Define Criteria
activities.description: Collaborate with the team to establish specific criteria (e.g., INVEST attributes, clear acceptance criteria) that make an item ready.

activities.name: Refine Backlog
activities.description: Evaluate and prepare backlog items against the DoR checklist during refinement sessions, ensuring fields like estimates and 'how to demo' are filled.

activities.name: Verify Readiness
activities.description: Confirm that high-priority items meet the agreed criteria before or during Sprint Planning to ensure smooth execution.

work_products.name: Definition of Ready Checklist
work_products.description: A shared list of criteria (e.g., dependencies resolved, acceptance criteria defined) used to gauge backlog items.

work_products.name: Ready Product Backlog Item
work_products.description: A backlog item that has passed the DoR criteria and is eligible for sprint planning.

completion_criteria: The team collectively agrees that the backlog item meets all defined DoR criteria.

metrics.name: Readiness Ratio
metrics.formula: (Items meeting DoR / Total Items selected for Sprint) * 100

guidelines.name: What is Definition of Ready | Atlassian
Scrum and XP from the Trenches

pitfalls: Gatekeeping behavior that impedes flow
Rigid adherence preventing necessary negotiability

benefits: Improves communication and aligns team expectations
Reduces back-and-forth and errors during the sprint
Ensures backlog items are actionable and feasible

name: A3 Report
objective: Summarize problem-solving, status, or planning on a single sheet
description:
The A3 Report is not merely a document; it is a structured problem-solving and continuous improvement process named after the ISO A3 paper size (approximately 11x17 inches) used to contain it. The physical constraint of the page forces the author to be concise, filter out noise, and focus only on the most critical facts and data. 

The process follows the PDCA (Plan-Do-Check-Act) logic. It requires the author to engage in 'Nemawashi' (consensus building) by discussing the A3 with stakeholders one-on-one before presenting it formally. The A3 serves as a storyboard that guides the dialogue between a mentor and a learner, shifting the management style from 'command and control' to 'leading through questioning.' There are three primary types of A3s: Problem Solving, Proposal, and Status Reporting.

activities.name: Identify Situation
activities.description: Define current situation and the nature of the issue (Background, Current Condition).

activities.name: Set Goals
activities.description: Define the target condition.

activities.name: Analyze
activities.description: Determine root causes (using 5 Whys, Fishbone).

activities.name: Propose Countermeasures
activities.description: Identify best countermeasures to address root causes.

activities.name: Plan Action
activities.description: Define who will do what, when, and how (Implementation Plan).

activities.name: Check Results
activities.description: Follow up and verify evidence that issue is addressed.

work_products.name: A3 Report
work_products.description: Single sheet document summarizing the problem solving process.

completion_criteria: A3 is completed and approved, and countermeasures are implemented.

pitfalls: Treating it as a form/template to fill out
Skipping analysis to jump to solutions
